awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  An Experimental Study of the Dynamics of Heated Contact Lines Using Combined High Resolution Thermography and Interferometry
awd_abstract_narration:
An Experimental Study of the Dynamics of Heated Contact Lines Using Combined High Resolution
Thermography and Interferometry

Understanding of evaporating thin films is essential to the development of devices used in a wide variety of industries including those involved in coating, microelectronics fabrication and packaging, chemical processing, and materials development. Although there is a good theoretical understanding of how these films behave, direct measurements of both the heat transfer and the thin film thickness to verify the theoretical predictions have never been made due to the very small length scales involved. This investigation will simultaneously employ, for the first time, two very powerful and complementary experimental techniques: 1) Fluorescence techniques to measure the temperature and heat flux in the vicinity of the contact line; and 2) Multi-wavelength, image analyzing interferometry/reflectometry that enables us to determine the shape of the vapor-liquid interface, the curvature and curvature gradient of that surface, and the adsorbed film thickness ahead of the contact line. The results will contribute to making these processes more efficient, ultimately saving energy, materials, and labor costs, and will affect the design and development of many technologies that operate by controlling contact line dynamics using interfacial energy gradients (e.g., heat pipes, boiling, spreading and wetting on unheated and heated surfaces, fuel cells, evaporation induced self-assembly, micro-chemical laboratories, etc.).

Many fundamental questions remain regarding the mechanisms by which energy is transferred in the interfacial region. With a completely wetting fluid, this region is characterized by a very thin adsorbed layer ahead of the contact line, by a region behind the contact line where the curvature of the vapor-liquid interface rapidly changes, and by a primary meniscus region where the curvature of the vapor-liquid interface is relatively constant. A partially wetting fluid may or may not have the adsorbed film. In addition, oscillations of the contact line have been observed in thin films on heated surfaces. The research will address fundamental phase-change heat and mass transfer questions by using interfacial energy gradients due to capillarity and disjoining pressure to naturally control the flow of simple fluids or dilute, ideal fluid mixtures. The validity of theoretical predictions regarding the structure and dynamics of the processes at the three-phase contact line will be investigated. The objectives of this work are: 1) To measure the shape of isothermal menisci using pure fluids and compare intermolecular forces obtained from those measurements with predicted values for various fluids on dielectric substrates; 2) To design, build, and operate an experiment to measure both the heat flux distribution and curvature as a function of position within the heated meniscus of pure fluids and to test current theories of interfacial transport in thin films; 3) To expand on the experiments with a pure fluid to include dilute, ideal mixtures and to test current theories of interfacial transport in thin films of mixtures; 4) To use these techniques to characterize contact line instability and oscillations for both the pure fluid and mixtures; and 5) To evaluate the degree to which molecular shape affects slip at the solid liquid interface and hence also affects transport processes in the contact line region. The fluorescence technique will allow direct measurement of the local heat flux and temperature. The interferometry/reflectometry technique will allow us to record what happens to the shape of the extended meniscus and the contact line as that energy gradient is perturbed, or to infer the local heat transfer from surface curvature measurements as the meniscus moves over the surface. Both techniques must be combined to obtain the data required to assess the current theories of interfacial transport.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The validity of theoretical predictions regarding the structure and dynamics of hydrodynamic and heat transfer processes at the three-phase contact line were investigated. The original scope of the proposal was to develop techniques to make sub-micron resolution temperature measurements using fluorophores such as quantum dots or temperature sensitive paints (TSP). It was found through experiments that the techniques (e-beam and liftoff methods) used to pattern the fluorophores damaged them or bled onto the surrounding areas, however, resulting in poor spatial resolution. The focus of the research thus shifted to making larger (25 micron resolution) measurements on an evaporating meniscus as it passed over a heated surface. The influence of meniscus speed, wall temperature, and gas concentration was investigated. 

A test section and flow loop were constructed to measure the heat flux under a moving contact line. A film of ruthenium based TSP was deposited onto one side of a plastic (PET) film then attached to a 12.7µm thick stainless-steel shim. The meniscus moved over this shim. Dots of ruthenium 0.5 mm in diameter on a 4 mm grid were deposited on the other side which was attached to a heated sapphire wafer. When calibrated, the TSP dots act as temperature sensors for the PET/sapphire interface while the TSP layer between the PET film and the stainless steel shim is used to measure the local wall temperature. The local heat flux at the fluid/wall (stainless steel) interface was determined by solving a 1-D transient conduction problem on the PET film using the sapphire temperature and the fluid side surface temperature as boundary conditions.

Results of the research indicated significant variations in the structure and wall heat transfer of the moving meniscus depending on the meniscus speed, wall temperature, and dissolved gas concentration. For cases where no dissolved gas was present, three profile types were observed. The first profile is a contact line characterized by a single peak in the heat flux where no microlayer forms as the meniscus passes. The second profile is consistent with microlayer formation with the length of the microlayer dependent on the meniscus speed and wall superheat. The third profile is one in which there is an area of elevated heat flux that follows the contact line. This is observed when the temperature of the stainless-steel, Tf, approaches the temperature of the sapphire, Ts. An example of results from a moving meniscus with high gas and low gas concentrations is shown in the figure.  Both have equal input heat fluxes (q” = 7.5kW/m2) and falling film speeds of about 16.5mm/s. The high gas case (left) shows an extended region of high heat flux indicating a slowly evaporating liquid layer is left on the surface. The region of high heat transfer for the low gas case (right) has a peak that is about twice as high and concentrated in the three-phase contact line region. Although the NSF funding has been concluded, research into this area continues to be performed.   

Broader Impacts. The work proposed here is of fundamental importance to a wide variety of industries including those involved in coating, microelectronics fabrication and packaging, chemical processing, and materials development. The results we obtain from this work will serve to make processes in all those industries more efficient and in so doing, save energy, materials, and labor costs. The female Ph.D student hired to perform the work is expected to graduate within 1-2 years. Results from the research will be published and a web sites at UMD will be set up to house the data to make it available to all interested parties. 

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Jungho Kim

Image
  • Heat flux and temperature maps for high gas concentration (left) and low gas concentration (right) under a moving meniscus of HFE7000
    Cathleen Needham and Jungho Kim
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jungho Kim
    Heat Flux and Temperature
